name: Asheville, NC
tagline: Progressive mountain oasis—stunning scenery, craft beer, and a glaring diversity problem

cost_of_living.index_vs_national: ~5-8% above national average (expensive for the South)

diversity.summary: ⚠️ HONEST WARNING: Asheville is VERY WHITE. Only 7.7% Black in 2024 (down from 10.5% in 2020). The city has a documented history of urban renewal that displaced its Black community. While Asheville is progressive and LGBTQ-friendly, it's overwhelmingly white and tourists are often more diverse than locals. Some commenters note feeling uncomfortable as part of an interracial couple. This is the WORST option on diversity—the #1 priority.
diversity.notable: Article headline: 'Where are all the Black people?' Asheville lost African American population

safety.summary: Asheville is generally very safe, especially in tourist and residential areas. Property crime (car break-ins) can occur but violent crime is low. Downtown feels safe. Smaller city vibe contributes to overall safety.

scenery.summary: SPECTACULAR. Blue Ridge Mountains surround the city. Fall colors are world-class. Hiking (Pisgah National Forest, Blue Ridge Parkway) is unmatched. Rivers, waterfalls, mountain vistas everywhere. If scenery is your priority, this is top-tier.

seasons.summary: Four seasons in the mountains—mild winters with some snow, warm (not hot) summers, stunning fall, pleasant spring. Higher elevation keeps temps moderate. Perfect climate for outdoor lovers. Occasional winter storm but manageable.

culture.summary: Asheville punches way above its weight—thriving craft beer scene (50+ breweries), farm-to-table dining, arts and music (buskers, venues), Biltmore Estate, River Arts District. Progressive, bohemian vibe with yoga studios, farmers markets, and crunchy granola ethos. Culture is rich but the whiteness is inescapable.

pros: BEST scenery on this list—Blue Ridge Mountains are breathtaking
Walkable downtown with mountain town charm
Excellent craft beer and food scene
Four seasons with mild mountain climate
cons: ⚠️ CRITICAL: Only 7.7% Black—Candace may feel isolated as an interracial couple
Documented history of displacing Black community (urban renewal)
Expensive for the region (tourism drives up costs)
Small city—may feel limited after 1-2 years
saturday: You wake up in your West Asheville bungalow to crisp mountain air and walk to Sunny Point Cafe, where the huevos rancheros are legendary. After breakfast, you drive the Blue Ridge Parkway, stopping at overlooks where the mountains fold into infinity—fall colors or spring blooms painting the ridgelines. By afternoon, you're hiking Rattlesnake Lodge trail or browsing the River Arts District studios, watching glass-blowers and potters work. Dinner is at Jerusalem Garden Cafe for warm pita and falafel, then you stroll downtown through the South Slope brewery district. As evening settles, you sit on your porch with a local IPA, watching the mountains fade to silhouette, feeling grateful for the beauty even if the homogeneity nags at you.

food_scene.summary: Asheville's food scene is exceptional for its size—James Beard semifinalists, 50+ craft breweries, and a farm-to-table ethos that actually delivers. The city takes its local sourcing seriously, with farmers markets fueling restaurant menus year-round.
mediterranean_options: Jerusalem Garden Cafe (authentic Middle Eastern, beloved for decades)
farmers_markets: Western North Carolina Farmers Market (year-round, daily)
food_scene.food_culture: Asheville's food culture is deeply rooted in Appalachian ingredients—ramps, sorghum, heritage grains—reinterpreted through modern techniques. The brewery scene is world-class (Wicked Weed, Highland, New Belgium), and restaurants like Cúrate (Spanish tapas) and Rhubarb (farm-to-table) draw national attention. It's a city that eats well.
food_scene.grocery_quality: Whole Foods, Trader Joe's, Earth Fare, and French Broad Food Co-op (member-owned, extensive local/organic selection). Excellent access to high-quality groceries.

neighborhoods.name: West Asheville
neighborhoods.vibe: Artsy, eclectic, slightly grittier than downtown—Asheville's hip side
neighborhoods.diversity_notes: Most diverse part of Asheville (still very white)
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Walkable, local shops/restaurants, more affordable. Best option for diversity in Asheville (which isn't saying much).

neighborhoods.name: Downtown/South Slope
neighborhoods.vibe: Tourist center meets brewery district—walkable, energetic
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Most walkable, near everything, brewery central. Can feel touristy. Good for short-term adventure.

neighborhoods.name: Historic Montford
neighborhoods.vibe: Victorian homes, tree-lined, residential charm near downtown
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Beautiful, walkable, historic. Safe and charming but homogeneous. May feel isolating.

neighborhoods.name: River Arts District
neighborhoods.vibe: Working studios and galleries in former industrial buildings
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Creative vibe, developing area. Less walkable but interesting. Gentrifying rapidly.

neighborhoods.name: North Asheville
neighborhoods.why_for_them: Safe, affordable, near trails. Not walkable. Feels suburban. Not recommended for their adventure goals.
